questions.text: All of the following statements are true regarding minimal change disease except:

options.label: A
options.text: It is the most common cause of nephrotic syndrome in children

options.label: B
options.text: Glomeruli are normal on light microscopy

options.label: C
options.text: Electron microscopy shows dense deposits along the GBM

options.label: D
options.text: Immunofluorescence study shows the absence of deposits

questions.correct_answer: C. Electron microscopy shows dense deposits along the GBM
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Electron microscopy shows dense deposits along the GBM Electron microscopy shows no significant deposits in minimal change disease. Only effacement of the podocyte foot process is seen.

Highyeild:

Minimal change disease Aka lipoid necrosis. A most common cause of nephrotic syndrome in children. Cause: Primary : idiopathic, triggered by infection, immunization, immune stimulus Secondary to lymphoma Diagnosis: Light microscopy: Normal glomeruli aka NIL disease. Immunofluorescence studies show no significant deposits or immune complexes in MCD. Electron microscopy: Effacement of podocyte foot process. Excellent response to glucocorticoids

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option:A., B., D. All are true

questions.text: Effacement of foot processes can be seen in:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

All of the above Effacement of foot processes can be seen in minimal change disease, membranous nephropathy, and diabetic nephropathy .

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A. Minimal change disease (MCD): A kidney disease that causes proteinuria, edema, and low levels of protein in the blood. Effacement of foot processes is a characteristic feature seen in MCD. Option: B. Membranous nephropathy (MN): A glomerular disease that is characterized by the thickening of the glomerular basement membrane due to the deposition of immune complexes. Effacement of foot processes can be seen in some cases of MN. Option: C. Diabetic nephropathy: A kidney disease that affects people with diabetes. It is characterized by damage to the glomeruli, leading to proteinuria, hypertension, and progressive renal failure. Effacement of foot processes is a late finding in diabetic nephropathy and is associated with the development of proteinuria.
